sub_title: Research to the adoption and uptake of 3D technology in archaeological practice
summary: Loes Opgenhaffen Archaeological Visualization (formerly known as LOPD) is specialized in 3D scanning and printing, 3D modelling, (3D-) reconstructions, manual and digital field and artefact drawing, illustration and design. I currently teach digital archaeology at the Saxion University of Applied Sciences and Technology. Loes Opgenhaffen recently obtained a PhD in Archeology at the University of Amsterdam on the thesis "Tradition in Transition". In this PhD project she explored how both past and modern practices respond to the introduction of new technology, such as the uptake, use and transmission of the potter’s wheel in the Late Bronze Age Aegean, and the nature of the adoption and application of new (digital 3D) visualization methods in archaeological practice.

Revello Lami, I. Kisjes and M. Louwaard. Exploring the possibilities of 3D scanning of pottery in order to enhance pottery analysis; development of an algorithm for automatic identification of ancient manufacturing techniques, frequently invisible to the naked eye but recognized through 3D scanning and the algorithm based on geometry; (subproject ‘Pottery goes Public’) demonstrating the process of this innovative archaeological research to the public by performing live at the ArcheoHotspot (Allard Pierson Museum) and the Satricum Museum (Italy) and involving the public in some pottery manufacturing experiments through 3D scanning and 3D printing. Presented on three conferences: CAA 2015 at Siena, EAA 2015 at Glasgow and CAA Netherlands - Flanders at Amsterdam.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Loes', 'last_name': 'Opgenhaffen', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research to the adoption and uptake of 3D technology in archaeological practice'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Muriel', 'last_name': 'Louwaard', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Documentalist/Informatiespecialist'}]}, {'title': 'Museum exhibition ‘Satricum.
